title: Isaiah Chapter 37 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 37 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 37 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 37.

questions.question: What did King Hezekiah do when he heard the news in Isaiah 37:1?
options: Rent his clothes and covered himself with sackcloth
Sent messengers to Assyria
Built a wall around Jerusalem
Fled to another city
questions.correctAnswer: Rent his clothes and covered himself with sackcloth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:1 states that King Hezekiah rent his clothes and covered himself with sackcloth when he heard the news.

questions.question: Who did Hezekiah send to Isaiah the prophet according to Isaiah 37:2?
options: Eliakim, Shebna, and the elders of the priests
Sennacherib and his army
Adrammelech and Sharezer
The king of Ethiopia
questions.correctAnswer: Eliakim, Shebna, and the elders of the priests
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:2 records that Hezekiah sent Eliakim, Shebna, and the elders of the priests to Isaiah the prophet.

questions.question: What message did Hezekiah's servants deliver to Isaiah in Isaiah 37:3?
options: This day is a day of trouble, rebuke, and blasphemy
The Assyrians have been defeated
Jerusalem will not fall
God has sent an angel to save us
questions.correctAnswer: This day is a day of trouble, rebuke, and blasphemy
questions.explanation: In Isaiah 37:3, the servants report to Isaiah that it is a day of trouble, rebuke, and blasphemy.

questions.question: What did Isaiah say the LORD would do to the king of Assyria in Isaiah 37:7?
options: Send a blast upon him causing him to hear a rumor and return home
Give him victory over Jerusalem
Send him angels to protect him
Allow him to conquer Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Send a blast upon him causing him to hear a rumor and return home
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:7 says the LORD will send a blast upon the king of Assyria, causing him to hear a rumor and return to his own land.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 37:10, what did the messengers from Assyria warn Hezekiah about?
options: Not to let his God deceive him about Jerusalem's safety
To prepare for battle immediately
To trust in the LORD for protection
To surrender to Assyria peacefully
questions.correctAnswer: Not to let his God deceive him about Jerusalem's safety
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:10 states the messengers warned Hezekiah not to let his God deceive him about Jerusalem not being given into the hand of Assyria.

questions.question: Where did Hezekiah go after reading the letter from the Assyrian messengers in Isaiah 37:14?
options: Into the house of the LORD
To the king of Ethiopia
To the city gates
To the Assyrian camp
questions.correctAnswer: Into the house of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:14 tells us Hezekiah went up into the house of the LORD and spread the letter before the LORD.

questions.question: In his prayer, how does Hezekiah describe God in Isaiah 37:16?
options: God of Israel dwelling between the cherubims, the only true God
A distant and unknown deity
One god among many in the earth
The god of Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: God of Israel dwelling between the cherubims, the only true God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:16 describes God as the LORD of hosts, God of Israel, who dwells between the cherubims and is the only true God.

questions.question: What did Hezekiah request from God in his prayer in Isaiah 37:20?
options: To save them from the hand of Sennacherib
To destroy all nations
To send a flood upon the Assyrians
To make the Assyrians his servants
questions.correctAnswer: To save them from the hand of Sennacherib
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:20 shows Hezekiah praying for God to save them from Sennacherib's hand so all kingdoms will know the LORD is God.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 37:22, how did the daughter of Zion respond to the king of Assyria?
options: She despised him and laughed him to scorn
She welcomed him with gifts
She surrendered peacefully
She fled the city
questions.correctAnswer: She despised him and laughed him to scorn
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:22 states that the virgin, the daughter of Zion, despised the king of Assyria and laughed him to scorn.

questions.question: What sign did God give as mentioned in Isaiah 37:30?
options: They shall eat what grows of itself for two years, then sow and reap in the third year
The sun will stand still
The moon will turn to blood
The Assyrians will build a wall around Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: They shall eat what grows of itself for two years, then sow and reap in the third year
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:30 gives the sign that the people will eat what grows by itself for two years and then sow and reap in the third year.

questions.question: How many Assyrian soldiers did the angel of the LORD strike down according to Isaiah 37:36?
options: One hundred and eighty-five thousand
Ten thousand
Fifty thousand
Two hundred thousand
questions.correctAnswer: One hundred and eighty-five thousand
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:36 states that the angel of the LORD smote 185,000 in the Assyrian camp.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 37:35 says God will save the city of Jerusalem for His own sake and for the sake of David.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:35 confirms that God will defend Jerusalem to save it for His own sake and for David's sake.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 37:38, Sennacherib was killed by his sons while worshipping in the house of Nisroch.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:38 records that Sennacherib was slain by his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer while worshipping in Nisroch's house.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 37:12 questions whether the gods of the nations saved the lands destroyed by Assyria.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:12 asks if the gods of the nations delivered those lands which Assyria destroyed, implying they did not.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Isaiah 37:16: 'O LORD of hosts, God of Israel, that dwellest between the ______, thou art the God, even thou alone, of all the kingdoms of the earth.'
options: cherubims
mountains
rivers
stars
questions.correctAnswer: cherubims
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:16 states God dwells between the cherubims, emphasizing His divine presence.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 37 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 37 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is overwhelmed with fear because of opposition. Based on Isaiah 37, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God?
options: Do not be afraid of the blasphemous words of enemies because the Lord will protect you
Rely on your own strength to fight the enemies
Ignore the threats and avoid prayer
Trust in military power alone for protection
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be afraid of the blasphemous words of enemies because the Lord will protect you
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:6-7 assures that God commands us not to fear the blasphemous words of enemies and promises to defend His people. This teaches reliance on God's protection rather than fear or self-reliance.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 37 teach us about the power of prayer during times of crisis and trial?
options: Prayer should be our first response to danger, asking God to save and reveal His glory
Prayer is unnecessary if we have strong armies
We should only pray after all else fails
Prayer can be replaced by wise political alliances
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer should be our first response to danger, asking God to save and reveal His glory
questions.explanation: Hezekiah's example in Isaiah 37:14-20 shows him turning to the Lord in prayer when faced with threat, asking God to save and demonstrate His power to the nations, highlighting prayer as the primary response.

questions.question: A believer doubts God's sovereignty during hardship. What does Isaiah 37 teach about God's control over all kingdoms?
options: God alone is the creator and ruler of all kingdoms on earth
God is limited to only one nation
God cannot influence earthly kings
The gods of nations are equal in power to the true God
questions.correctAnswer: God alone is the creator and ruler of all kingdoms on earth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:16 emphasizes God's unique sovereignty as creator of heaven and earth and ruler over all kingdoms, comforting believers that God is in control despite worldly powers.

questions.question: How does the chapter Isaiah 37 encourage believers to respond to blasphemy and insults against God?
options: Trust God to defend His honor and do not be shaken by enemy's words
Respond with anger and retaliation
Ignore the situation completely
Join in mocking those who insult God
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to defend His honor and do not be shaken by enemy's words
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:6 and 23 show God’s message to not fear blasphemous words and affirm that God Himself will punish those who reproach Him, teaching believers to trust God rather than react in anger.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 37 reveal about God’s faithfulness to His promises and people?
options: God will defend Jerusalem for His own sake and for David’s sake
God abandons His people in times of trouble
God only helps those who are strong and wealthy
God’s promises depend on human strength
questions.correctAnswer: God will defend Jerusalem for His own sake and for David’s sake
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:35 declares God’s commitment to defend Jerusalem for His own glory and because of His covenant with David, assuring believers of God's faithfulness during trials.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with discouragement after seeing enemies thrive. Based on Isaiah 37, how should they view the destruction of false gods and idols?
options: False gods are powerless and will be destroyed because they are man-made
False gods can protect nations from destruction
Idols have real power to save
Destruction of idols is a sign that God has abandoned His people
questions.correctAnswer: False gods are powerless and will be destroyed because they are man-made
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:18-19 explains that the gods of nations are merely wood and stone made by men and have been destroyed, emphasizing God's supremacy and the futility of idols.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 37 teach about humility and contentment in the face of enemy boasting?
options: God humbles the proud who boast of their strength and achievements
We should boast about our own power and accomplishments
Ignore God and trust only in human plans
Accept enemy boasts as truth without question
questions.correctAnswer: God humbles the proud who boast of their strength and achievements
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:23-29 recounts God’s judgment on Sennacherib’s arrogance and boastful claims, teaching believers to remain humble and trust God rather than human strength.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 37, God’s intervention in times of trial can result in miraculous deliverance.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:36 describes how the angel of the Lord struck down 185,000 Assyrian soldiers, demonstrating miraculous deliverance by God in response to prayer.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 37 teaches that human efforts alone are sufficient to overcome great challenges without God’s help.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The chapter shows Hezekiah’s reliance on prayer and God’s promise of protection (Isaiah 37:14-20, 33-35), emphasizing that human efforts without God’s help are not enough.

questions.question: A fellow believer is worried about the future and asks for encouragement about perseverance. Based on Isaiah 37, what hope can you share?
options: The remnant of God's people will take root and bear fruit again
All hope is lost during trials
Only physical strength matters for survival
God favors only perfect people without trials
questions.correctAnswer: The remnant of God's people will take root and bear fruit again
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:31-32 promises that a remnant of Judah will survive, grow, and prosper by God’s zeal, encouraging perseverance and hope.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 37 demonstrate the importance of humility and seeking God in leadership?
options: Hezekiah humbled himself, prayed, and sought God’s guidance in crisis
Hezekiah relied solely on military might
Hezekiah ignored prophets and acted independently
Leaders should avoid showing weakness by not praying
questions.correctAnswer: Hezekiah humbled himself, prayed, and sought God’s guidance in crisis
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:1-3 and 14-20 show Hezekiah’s humility in tearing his clothes and praying to God, setting an example of reliance on God’s wisdom and power.

questions.question: Based on Isaiah 37, how should believers respond to threats against their faith and community?
options: Pray earnestly and trust God to defend and deliver
Retaliate violently without seeking God's help
Ignore the threats and avoid fellowship
Compromise faith to avoid conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Pray earnestly and trust God to defend and deliver
questions.explanation: Hezekiah and the people responded to Assyrian threats by prayer and trusting God’s promise to protect Jerusalem (Isaiah 37:14-20, 33-35), teaching believers to respond with faith and prayer.

questions.question: What biblical principle about God’s justice and judgment is taught in Isaiah 37?
options: God will bring judgment on proud enemies who blaspheme Him
God ignores insults and injustice
God favors wicked nations over His people
Judgment is solely human responsibility
questions.correctAnswer: God will bring judgment on proud enemies who blaspheme Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:23-29 shows God's promise to punish Sennacherib’s pride and blasphemy, reminding believers that God upholds justice and defends His honor.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Isaiah 37, God promises that the remnant that escapes will ________ and bear fruit.
options: take root downward
be scattered abroad
be forgotten
be destroyed
questions.correctAnswer: take root downward
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:31 states the remnant will 'take root downward, and bear fruit upward,' symbolizing restoration and hope after trial.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 37 encourage believers to maintain integrity and trust during difficult times?
options: By trusting God’s promises and praying honestly in faith
By deceiving others to gain advantage
By avoiding God when life is hard
By relying on worldly wisdom alone
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting God’s promises and praying honestly in faith
questions.explanation: Hezekiah’s sincere prayer in Isaiah 37:14-20 shows the importance of honest communication with God and trusting His word during trials.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 37 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 37.

questions.question: What immediate action did King Hezekiah take upon hearing the threatening news from Assyria?
options: He rent his clothes and covered himself with sackcloth
He gathered his army and prepared for battle
He sent messengers to Egypt for help
He built additional fortifications around Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: He rent his clothes and covered himself with sackcloth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:1 describes Hezekiah's response to the threat as tearing his clothes and covering himself with sackcloth, signifying mourning and supplication.

questions.question: Who did King Hezekiah send to consult the prophet Isaiah?
options: Eliakim, Shebna, and the elders of the priests
Jeremiah and the Levites
The chief captains and scribes
The priests and the king’s counselors
questions.correctAnswer: Eliakim, Shebna, and the elders of the priests
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:2 states that Hezekiah sent Eliakim, who was over the household, Shebna the scribe, and the elders of the priests to Isaiah the prophet.

questions.question: In Hezekiah's prayer, how does he identify God’s dwelling place?
options: Between the cherubims
On Mount Zion
In the temple of Jerusalem
In the heavens above
questions.correctAnswer: Between the cherubims
questions.explanation: Hezekiah addresses God as the one who dwells between the cherubims in Isaiah 37:16, a reference to the Ark of the Covenant’s mercy seat imagery.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'the daughter of Zion' laughing and shaking her head at Sennacherib?
options: It symbolizes Jerusalem’s confidence and contempt toward Assyria
It refers to a prophetic vision of a future queen
It indicates the people's despair and hopelessness
It is a metaphor for the destruction of the city
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes Jerusalem’s confidence and contempt toward Assyria
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:22 uses the figure 'daughter of Zion' to personify Jerusalem, showing scorn and defiance against the Assyrian king’s threats.

questions.question: What literary device is used in the passage where God's response to Sennacherib's arrogance is detailed (Isaiah 37:23-29)?
options: Chiasm
Parable
Simile
Allegory
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm
questions.explanation: The passage exhibits chiastic structure, emphasizing God's sovereignty and the futility of Sennacherib’s boastful claims.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 37, what was the LORD’s purpose in saving Jerusalem?
options: For His own sake and for the sake of His servant David
To show His power to the kings of Assyria
To expand Israel’s territory
To fulfill a covenant with Hezekiah
questions.correctAnswer: For His own sake and for the sake of His servant David
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:35 states God’s defense of Jerusalem was for His own name’s sake and for the legacy of David, linking to covenant promises.

questions.question: What was the fate of the Assyrian army as described in Isaiah 37?
options: An angel of the LORD smote 185,000 in the camp
They were defeated in a great battle by Judah’s army
They fled after a plague struck their camp
They surrendered and withdrew peacefully
questions.correctAnswer: An angel of the LORD smote 185,000 in the camp
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:36 records that the angel of the LORD killed 185,000 Assyrian soldiers overnight, causing their defeat without direct battle.

questions.question: How does the chapter foreshadow New Testament themes of divine deliverance?
options: God’s intervention to save His people prefigures Christ’s salvation
It predicts the coming destruction of Jerusalem
It prophesies the rise of the Roman Empire
It shows the futility of trusting in human armies
questions.correctAnswer: God’s intervention to save His people prefigures Christ’s salvation
questions.explanation: The chapter’s theme of God delivering His people from overwhelming odds anticipates the ultimate salvation through Christ found in the New Testament.

questions.question: Which historical context best explains the Assyrian threat in Isaiah 37?
options: The Assyrian Empire’s expansion under Sennacherib targeting Judah
The Babylonian captivity period
The Egyptian invasions of Israel
The Persian conquest of Judea
questions.correctAnswer: The Assyrian Empire’s expansion under Sennacherib targeting Judah
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37 reflects the historical siege of Jerusalem by Assyria’s King Sennacherib, a major event in the late 8th century BCE.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 37, the gods of the nations were able to save their lands from Assyrian destruction.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:19 explains that the gods of other nations were cast into fire as they were mere idols made by human hands and could not save their people.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the Hebrew word translated as 'blast' in Isaiah 37:7, signifying God's judgment against Assyria?
options: Ruach (spirit or wind)
Shema (hearing)
Chesed (mercy)
Malak (messenger)
questions.correctAnswer: Ruach (spirit or wind)
questions.explanation: The word 'blast' corresponds to the Hebrew 'ruach,' meaning spirit or wind, symbolizing a divine force sent to scatter and defeat the enemy.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 37:30 promises a sign to the people that they will eat the fruit of their labor in the _____ and _____ years following the siege.
options: first, second
second, third
third, fourth
first, third
questions.correctAnswer: first, second
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:30 states they will eat what grows of itself the first year and the same the second year, indicating restoration after judgment.

questions.question: Who succeeded Sennacherib as king of Assyria according to Isaiah 37?
options: Esarhaddon
Adrammelech
Sharezer
Tiglath-Pileser
questions.correctAnswer: Esarhaddon
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:38 reports that after Sennacherib was slain by his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer, his son Esarhaddon reigned in his place.

questions.question: What is the significance of Hezekiah spreading the Assyrian letter before the LORD in the temple?
options: It symbolizes presenting the problem directly to God for intervention
It was a ritual to curse the enemy
It was meant to intimidate the priests
It showed Hezekiah’s rejection of the message
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes presenting the problem directly to God for intervention
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:14 shows Hezekiah laying out the letter before God, a symbolic act of surrendering the crisis to divine judgment.

questions.question: Which phrase best captures the theme of divine sovereignty in Isaiah 37?
options: "Thou art the God, even thou alone, of all the kingdoms of the earth"
"By the multitude of my chariots I have come up"
"Have the gods of the nations delivered?"
"An angel smote the camp of the Assyrians"
questions.correctAnswer: "Thou art the God, even thou alone, of all the kingdoms of the earth"
questions.explanation: Hezekiah’s prayer in Isaiah 37:16 affirms God’s exclusive sovereignty over all kingdoms, a central theological assertion.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 37 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 37 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was King Hezekiah's immediate response upon hearing the threat against Jerusalem?
options: He rent his clothes and went into the house of the LORD
He sent soldiers to fight immediately
He ignored the threat
He sought alliance with other nations
questions.correctAnswer: He rent his clothes and went into the house of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:1 records that Hezekiah rent his clothes, covered himself with sackcloth, and went into the house of the LORD, showing his humility and dependence on God. This response aligns with biblical examples of repentance and seeking God in times of crisis (Psalm 34:18, 2 Chronicles 20:3, Joel 2:13, Jonah 3:6-10).

questions.question: Who did Hezekiah send to consult Isaiah the prophet about the threat from Assyria?
options: Eliakim, Shebna, and the elders of the priests
His military generals
The king of Ethiopia
The people of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Eliakim, Shebna, and the elders of the priests
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:2 states that Hezekiah sent Eliakim, who was over the household, Shebna the scribe, and the elders of the priests to Isaiah. This demonstrates the importance of seeking divine guidance through God's appointed leaders (Exodus 18:13-26, 1 Kings 22:5, Acts 13:1, Hebrews 1:1-2).

questions.question: What did Hezekiah describe as the condition of the people in his message to Isaiah?
options: The children are come to the birth, and there is not strength to bring forth
The walls of Jerusalem are strong and unbreachable
The army is well-prepared and confident
The people have abandoned the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: The children are come to the birth, and there is not strength to bring forth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:3 describes Hezekiah's words expressing extreme distress and helplessness likened to a woman in labor without strength. This imagery depicts human frailty and the need for divine intervention (Psalm 22:9-10, John 16:21, Romans 8:22-23, 2 Corinthians 1:8-9).

questions.question: What assurance did Isaiah give to Hezekiah regarding the Assyrian threat?
options: The LORD will send a blast upon the Assyrians and cause them to return to their own land
Hezekiah must rally more troops to fight
The Assyrians will surely conquer Jerusalem
Hezekiah should surrender to save lives
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will send a blast upon the Assyrians and cause them to return to their own land
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:6-7 records God's promise through Isaiah that He will send a blast causing the Assyrians to hear a rumor and return home, where they will fall by the sword. This demonstrates God's sovereign control over nations (Psalm 2:4-6, Daniel 2:21, Acts 17:26, Romans 13:1).

questions.question: How did Rabshakeh attempt to undermine Hezekiah's trust in God?
options: By claiming that Hezekiah's God would not deliver Jerusalem from Assyria
By praising the God of Israel
By offering peace negotiations
By warning Hezekiah of a greater enemy
questions.correctAnswer: By claiming that Hezekiah's God would not deliver Jerusalem from Assyria
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:10 shows Rabshakeh mocking Hezekiah's trust by saying, 'Let not thy God deceive thee,' denying God's power to save Jerusalem. This is a common tactic of blasphemy and testing God's sovereignty (Psalm 73:11, Job 1:11, Mark 15:29-32, Hebrews 3:8).

questions.question: What argument did Rabshakeh use to question the power of Hezekiah's God?
options: He pointed to the destruction of other lands and their gods by Assyria
He claimed Hezekiah was a false king
He argued that Jerusalem had no walls
He said the people of Judah worship false idols
questions.correctAnswer: He pointed to the destruction of other lands and their gods by Assyria
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:11-12 recounts Rabshakeh's argument that other gods of nations failed to deliver them from Assyria's destruction, implying Judah's God would not be different. This challenges God's unique power and calls for faith in His deliverance (Exodus 15:11, Isaiah 46:9-10, Jeremiah 10:10, John 10:27-29).

questions.question: What was Hezekiah's response after reading the threatening letter from the Assyrians?
options: He went up to the house of the LORD and spread the letter before the LORD
He destroyed the letter and ignored it
He sent a counter-letter threatening Assyria
He fled the city
questions.correctAnswer: He went up to the house of the LORD and spread the letter before the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:14 shows Hezekiah bringing the letter to God in prayer, demonstrating reliance on divine help rather than human strength alone, consistent with biblical patterns of petition (Psalm 25:1-2, Daniel 6:10, Philippians 4:6, 1 Peter 5:7).

questions.question: In Hezekiah's prayer, how does he describe God in relation to all kingdoms of the earth?
options: The God of Israel alone who made heaven and earth
One god among many
A powerless deity
A god of only Judah
questions.correctAnswer: The God of Israel alone who made heaven and earth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:16 declares God as the sole Creator and sovereign over all kingdoms, affirming monotheism and divine transcendence (Genesis 1:1, Deuteronomy 4:35, Isaiah 45:5-7, John 1:3).

questions.question: What reason does Hezekiah give for asking God to save Jerusalem from Assyria's hand?
options: So that all kingdoms of the earth may know that the LORD is God alone
Because Jerusalem had a strong army
Because the Assyrians were weak
So that Hezekiah could rule longer
questions.correctAnswer: So that all kingdoms of the earth may know that the LORD is God alone
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:20 highlights the purpose of salvation being God's glory and universal recognition, consistent with God's desire for all nations to know Him (Psalm 96:3, Isaiah 49:6, Romans 15:9-11, Revelation 15:4).

questions.question: According to Isaiah's prophecy, how does the LORD describe the daughter of Zion's attitude toward Sennacherib?
options: She has despised him and laughed him to scorn
She is fearful and trembling
She seeks to negotiate peace
She is indifferent
questions.correctAnswer: She has despised him and laughed him to scorn
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:22 portrays a confident and defiant Jerusalem, symbolized as the daughter of Zion, showing trust in God despite threats, reflecting God's protection of His people (Psalm 48:11, Zephaniah 3:14, Romans 8:31, Hebrews 13:6).

questions.question: What does God say He will do to Sennacherib because of his rage against Him?
options: Put a hook in his nose and a bridle in his lips to turn him back
Give him victory over Jerusalem
Make him king of Israel
Ignore his threats
questions.correctAnswer: Put a hook in his nose and a bridle in his lips to turn him back
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:29 uses metaphorical language to describe God's sovereign control over Sennacherib's actions, emphasizing divine judgment and restraint, paralleling God's guiding of nations (Psalm 8:6, Job 12:23, Isaiah 10:5-7, Romans 9:17).

questions.question: What sign does God give about the future agricultural recovery after the Assyrian threat?
options: Eat what grows by itself for two years, and sow and reap in the third year
There will be famine for seven years
No crops will grow for a decade
The land will be permanently barren
questions.correctAnswer: Eat what grows by itself for two years, and sow and reap in the third year
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:30 forecasts a period of divine restoration and blessing following judgment, showing God's providential care and hope for renewal (Leviticus 26:4-6, Jeremiah 31:12, Joel 2:23, Matthew 13:31-32).

questions.question: What does the LORD promise concerning the remnant of the house of Judah?
options: They shall take root downward and bear fruit upward
They will be completely destroyed
They will be scattered with no hope
They will become Assyrian subjects
questions.correctAnswer: They shall take root downward and bear fruit upward
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:31 uses agricultural imagery to describe the spiritual and national restoration of God's people, consistent with biblical themes of hope and covenant faithfulness (Jeremiah 23:3, Ezekiel 37:11-14, Romans 11:5, Revelation 7:9).

questions.question: Why will the king of Assyria not enter Jerusalem or attack it, according to the LORD?
options: Because God will defend the city for His own sake and for David's sake
Because the city surrendered
Because the Assyrians ran out of supplies
Because the people fled
questions.correctAnswer: Because God will defend the city for His own sake and for David's sake
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:33-35 emphasizes God's covenant faithfulness and protective power, preserving Jerusalem for His glory and in remembrance of His servant David, illustrating God's unchanging promises (2 Samuel 7:12-16, Psalm 89:3-4, Acts 13:22-23, Hebrews 13:5).

questions.question: What calamity befell the Assyrian army as described in the chapter?
options: The angel of the LORD smote 185,000 in their camp
They were defeated in battle by Judah's forces
They fled due to famine
They were struck by a plague of locusts
questions.correctAnswer: The angel of the LORD smote 185,000 in their camp
questions.explanation: Isaiah 37:36 recounts a divine intervention where the angel of the LORD struck down the Assyrian army, a demonstration of God's power to save His people supernaturally (Exodus 12:23, 2 Kings 19:35, Psalm 34:7, Revelation 15:1).
